Case 8-3
Continuing Treatment of a Patient Who Will Not Pay Her Bills
A thoracic surgeon, Beau Schenker, MD, was called to the Emergency De-
partment to evaluate and treat Nelda Thomas, a 40-year-old female who
had chest pain of sudden onset. Her history pointed to lung disease, not
cardiac problems. The exam revealed decreased breath sounds in the left
chest, and x-rays confirmed free air in the chest that had collapsed the left
lung. Dr. Schenker determined that the patient had a spontaneous pneumo-
thorax. He discussed with Ms. Thomas the well-established treatment: a
chest tube. Dr. Schenker stated, “We will need to insert a small tube into
your chest to withdraw the air and allow the lung to re-expand.”
Ms. Thomas and her husband were relieved to learn that the chest pain
was not the result of a heart problem and agreed quickly to the procedure,
which was successful.
During the brief hospital stay, Dr. Schenker and Mr. Thomas, the pa-
tient's husband, reminisced about their days in high school since they co-
incidentally attended the same school. Ms. Thomas was seen several times
for appropriate follow-up in Dr. Schenker's office after her hospitalization.
Several months later, Dr. Schenker’s business manager reported that the
balance of Ms. Thomas's bill had not been paid. Since Dr. Schenker’s office
had a policy of not using collection companies, Dr. Schenker said “write the
bill off.”
Two years later, Ms. Thomas was once again in the emergency room
(ER) for recurrence of the same problem. She requested to be seen by
Dr. Schenker. When the Emergency Department paged Dr. Schenker, he ad-
vised the staff to call another available thoracic surgeon to see Ms. Thomas.
A few minutes later, Mr. Thomas called Dr. Schenker directly at his office.
Mr. Thomas admitted he had not paid the earlier bill (although Dr. Schenker
had not brought up the matter) and promised to pay the old balance and
then prepay for the costs of his wife's current needs. Dr. Schenken replied,
“It's not about the money but about mutual respect. I am sorry but I cannot
take care of your wife at this time. Another thoracic surgeon will take the
case so you have nothing to worry about.” Ms. Thomas was treated suc-
cessfully by another physician. Should Dr. Schenker have relented and
taken the case the second time?

data.vignette: A 40-year-old woman returns to the ED with sudden pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. Imaging again shows a left spontaneous pneumothorax. She is stable but uncomfortable, and the ED team wants a thoracic surgeon to place a chest tube now and to discuss whether she should have definitive pleural surgery during this admission. Two years ago you treated her for the same problem and provided follow-up, but she never paid the balance despite repeated reminders; your small practice absorbed the loss and has a standing policy of limiting nonemergent services for patients with unresolved bills. She asks specifically for you and says she trusts you. Another credentialed thoracic surgeon is in the hospital and can take the consult without delaying care. Hospital policy and counsel confirm either physician may assume the case if coverage is ensured.
data.choice_1: Personally take over her care for this admission.
data.choice_2: Transfer the consult to the other thoracic surgeon.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove language implying a medically “correct” or superior path. Replace “definitive pleural surgery” with a neutral, balanced description such as: “consider inpatient VATS blebectomy/pleurodesis during this admission (which may reduce recurrence but carries operative pain, anesthesia risk, and time off work), versus treating this episode with a chest tube and arranging outpatient follow-up.” Avoid the word “definitive” unless paired with explicit tradeoffs.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Increase the moral/clinical stakes of transferring the consult so it is not a near–free-lunch. For example: (1) Clarify that she is willing to accept emergent tube placement but is strongly opposed to having definitive pleural surgery unless you recommend it, and may decline surgery or leave if you refuse; (2) Specify that you have unique longitudinal knowledge (e.g., prior operative findings, complex pleural disease, medication intolerance) that would materially affect counseling/plan—without stating you are objectively 'better'—so transferring risks miscommunication, loss of trust, or suboptimal shared decision-making; (3) Strengthen the competing cost of taking the case by stating your practice’s policy is applied uniformly to protect solvency and avoid preferential exceptions, and that personally taking over would undermine staff morale/consistency and create pressure to waive similar debts in future. Reframe the decision point as occurring now because the team needs a surgeon to consent her tonight for possible surgery tomorrow, making refusal/transfer immediately consequential.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove language that frames nonpayment as blameworthy (e.g., delete “never paid…despite repeated reminders” and “absorbed the loss”), and replace with neutral, factual phrasing such as “has an outstanding balance from prior care.” Avoid “specifically for you and says she trusts you” unless balanced with a neutral note that she is open to other surgeons if care is timely.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the decision point: specify whether the immediate decision is chest tube placement vs elective pleurodesis/pleurectomy, and whether the consult transfer would occur before or after initial stabilization. Remove redundant or narrative elements (e.g., “small practice absorbed the loss”) and keep only facts needed to understand the conflict and urgency.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make choices ~10–15 words and include the complete action. Example: (1) “Accept the consult and provide chest tube and operative management this admission.” (2) “Decline the consult and hand off all inpatient thoracic care to the on-call surgeon.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes:
Reduce the implicit moral asymmetry that makes transferring feel like punishing a patient in an emergency. Edits:
- Add a concrete, weighty downside to personally taking over beyond “unpaid bill,” e.g., “your practice is close to insolvency; another large unpaid admission could force layoffs/closure, limiting access for your existing patients,” or “you are the only surgeon covering complex postoperative patients in your practice tomorrow and an added admission would compromise their safety.”
- Add a concrete downside to transferring that is more than mere preference, e.g., “she has a prior operative note/complication history you uniquely know; new surgeon may reasonably recommend a different approach that she previously found unacceptable,” or “she has trauma history and becomes agitated with unfamiliar clinicians, risking refusal of indicated tube/analgesia.”
- Make clear that either surgeon can provide equally timely, competent clinical care, so the dilemma stays value-based rather than ‘good care vs abandonment.’

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
As written, there are obvious middle-ground options. Close off or explicitly rule out hybrids such as:
- You place the chest tube now (emergent) but transfer the rest of the admission/definitive pleural surgery decision to the other surgeon.
- Shared care/second-opinion model (you counsel, other surgeon operates).
- You agree to care contingent on a payment plan/charity-care evaluation.
To make it truly binary, specify constraints like: “ED policy requires a single attending thoracic surgeon to assume full responsibility for the admission (tube + operative planning) and handoffs after accepting are not permitted except for emergencies,” and “the patient refuses to proceed unless one surgeon is fully responsible.”

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes:
The case risks being determined by professional/organizational obligations (on-call duty, anti-abandonment standards, EMTALA-like expectations) rather than judgment. Clarify:
- You are NOT the on-call surgeon and have no contractual obligation to accept the consult.
- The hospital’s emergency coverage is fully met by the other in-house surgeon with no delay.
- The ‘standing policy’ applies to discretionary/nonemergent surgeon selection and does not violate any hospital or state rules; counsel confirms both options are permissible.
Optionally add: “Hospital policy is silent on patient-physician financial disputes for specialist choice once emergency coverage is ensured,” to keep it in the gray zone.

data.vignette: A 40-year-old woman returns to the ED with sudden pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. Imaging shows a recurrent left spontaneous pneumothorax. She is stable but in pain and likely needs a chest tube tonight. The admitting team also wants a plan for either inpatient VATS blebectomy/pleurodesis during this admission or chest tube management with outpatient follow-up. You treated her for the same problem two years ago and have an outstanding balance for that care; your group applies a uniform policy of limiting elective services for unresolved balances because the practice is financially strained and you are scheduled tomorrow as the only surgeon covering several complex postoperative patients. She says she will proceed only if one surgeon assumes full responsibility for the admission, and ED policy requires a single attending to manage the tube and any operative planning with no planned handoff once accepted. Another credentialed thoracic surgeon is in-house and can take the consult without delaying care. Hospital counsel confirms either course is permissible if coverage is ensured.
data.choice_1: Accept the consult and manage the chest tube and operative plan this admission.
data.choice_2: Decline the consult and have the in-house thoracic surgeon assume full care.

choice_1.choice: Accept the consult and manage the chest tube and operative plan this admission.

choice_2.choice: Decline the consult and have the in-house thoracic surgeon assume full care.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add that she explicitly refuses care from any other surgeon (e.g., "She refuses transfer of care to the in-house thoracic surgeon and will leave AMA unless you personally take the case").

Add a clause specifying that if you accept, your next-day solo coverage for complex postop patients would likely delay chest-tube troubleshooting/definitive VATS timing or reduce bedside availability compared with the in-house surgeon.

Add a clause stating that if you accept this admission, your overnight/next-day workload would likely delay monitoring or increase procedural/operative risk (e.g., "accepting would stretch you thin and could compromise chest tube management and your complex postop patients' safety").

Add a clause that if you accept, you would have to defer/hand off care for your complex postoperative patients tomorrow due to being the only covering surgeon; and add that if you decline, the in-house thoracic surgeon can place the chest tube and arrange needed VATS during the same admission with no delay or difference in access despite the outstanding balance.

data.vignette: A 40-year-old woman returns to the ED with pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. Imaging shows a recurrent left spontaneous pneumothorax. She is stable but in pain and likely needs a chest tube tonight. The team wants a plan for inpatient VATS blebectomy/pleurodesis this admission versus chest tube management with outpatient follow-up. You treated her for the same problem two years ago and she has an outstanding balance. Your group has a uniform policy of limiting elective services for unresolved balances because the practice is financially strained. She will accept care only if you take full responsibility for the admission. She refuses transfer to the in-house thoracic surgeon and says she will leave if you do not assume care. ED policy requires a single attending with no planned handoff once accepted. You are scheduled tomorrow as the only surgeon covering several complex postoperative patients, and accepting this admission would reduce your bedside availability and could delay chest tube troubleshooting or VATS timing. Another credentialed thoracic surgeon is in-house and can place the tube and arrange VATS during this admission without delaying care despite the balance. Hospital counsel confirms either course is permissible if coverage is ensured.

choice_1.choice: Accept the consult and manage the chest tube and operative plan this admission.

choice_2.choice: Decline the consult and have the in-house thoracic surgeon assume full care.
